abstract.p: Live, one-on-one college advisory services, which has been offered primarily offline, is now available at PureAdvice.com (S)

block.p: Live, one-on-one college advisory services, offered until now primarily offline, became available on the Internet last Friday through a new Web site, PureAdvice.com. It is offering tools and services to help high school students identify and apply to colleges appropriate for them and apply for and obtain financial aid.
Some information, like extensive data on all the colleges in the United States, and a calculator that estimates the total expense of going to college, is free.

Live, one-on-one college advisory services, offered until now primarily offline, became available on the Internet last Friday through a new Web site, PureAdvice.com. It is offering tools and services to help high school students identify and apply to colleges appropriate for them and apply for and obtain financial aid.
Some information, like extensive data on all the colleges in the United States, and a calculator that estimates the total expense of going to college, is free.

But live, one-on-one counseling sessions with experienced guidance counselors, financial aid experts and former college admissions officials involve fees that start at $75 for a 45-minute session. Included in this fee is a written report summarizing the session, which is sent to the student and to the student's guidance counselor, if desired.
PureAdvice.com's president, Steven Ehrlich, said 140 advisers from across the country, each with a minimum of five years' experience, conduct the online sessions.

''In-school guidance counselors are often overburdened. PureAdvice will help change that, giving students, their parents and guidance counselors the tools and personalized attention they deserve,'' Mr. Ehrlich said.
PureAdvice also receives fees for referring visitors to vendors -- like student loan providers -- that are listed on its site.

In addition, the company has formed a partnership with U.S. News & World Report to provide its counseling services on the portion of the magazine's Web site that carries its annual college survey. Mr. Ehrlich said U.S. News & World Report would receive a fee for each referral to PureAdvice.com.
Officials of Achieva.com, a three-year-old, San Mateo, Calif., company that also helps high school students with the college admissions process, appeared undaunted by the East Coast start-up.
Steven Feuling, Achieva.com's vice president for marketing, said his company's $295 online college program ''takes you through everything, not just college selection and the financial aid piece.''

''We help you with test preparation, developing an extra-curricular resume, with an application strategy.'' The company also offers live counseling, but not online. He said more than half Achieva's income was derived from sales directly to school systems.
